column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.3
#T_SP=custom.Span|label
#T_RL=custom.Relation|label|BT_custom.Span
#Text=Of Beasts living in the Water.
#Text=Their Otters are most of them black, and their skins are almost as good
#Text=as Bevers; Their Oyl is of rare use for many things.
#Text=Martins also have a
#Text=good Fur for their bigness.
#Text=Musquashes are almost like Beavers, but
#Text=not so big, the Males stones smells as sweet as Musk, and being killed
#Text=in Winter or the Spring they never loose their sweetness: they are no
#Text=bigger than Cony-skins, and yet are sold for five shillings a piece.
#Text=One
#Text=good Skin will perfume a whole house full of Clothes.
#Text=The Bevers
#Text=wisdom and understanding makes him come nigh to a reasonable creature.
#Text=His body is thick and short, with short leggs, feet like a Mole before,
#Text=and behind like a Goose, a broad tail like a shoo-sole, very tough
#Text=and strong: His head is something like an Otters, saving that his foreeteth
#Text=be like Conies, two above and two beneath, sharp and broad, with
#Text=which he cuts down Trees as big as a mans thigh, or bigger, which afterwards
#Text=he divides into lengths according to the uses they are appoinetd
#Text=for.
#Text=If one Beaver be too weak to carry the Log, than another helps
#Text=him: If two be too weak, three or four will assist, being placed three
#Text=to three, which set their teeth in one anothers tough tails, and laying
#Text=the load on the hindermost, they draw the Logg to the desired place, they
#Text=tow it in the water, the youngest getting under it, bearing it up that it
#Text=may swim the lighter.
#Text=They build their houses of Wood and Clay,
#Text=close by a Ponds side, and knowing their seasons, they build their houses
#Text=answerably, three stories high, that when the Land Floods come they
#Text=may shift higher, and when the waters fall, they remove lower.
#Text=These
#Text=houses are so strong that no Creature, save an industrious man with his
#Text=penetrating tools can pierce them, their ingress and egress being under
#Text=water.
#Text=They make very good Ponds; for knowing where a stream
#Text=runs from between two rising Hills, they will pitch down Piles of Wood
#Text=placing smaller Rubbish before it, with clay and sods, not leaving till by
#Text=their Art and Industry they have made a firm and curious Dam-head,
#Text=which may cause admiration in wise men.
#Text=They keep themselves to
#Text=their own Families, never parting so long as they are able to keep house
#Text=together.
#Text=Their wisdom secures them from the English, who seldom
#Text=kill any of them, wanting time and patience to lay a long siege, or to
#Text=be often deceived by their cunning evasions.
#Text=So that all our Beavers
#Text=come from the Indians, whose time and experience fits them for that
#Text=imployment.
#Text=Of the Birds, and Fowls both of Land and Water.
#Text=They are expressed in these Verses.
#Text=The princely Eagle, and the soaring Hawks,
#Text=Within their unknown wayes ther ' s none can chawk:
#Text=The Hum-Bird for some Queens rich Cage more fit
#Text=Than in the vacant wilderness to sit.
#Text=The swift-wing ' d Swallow sweeping to and fro,
#Text=As swift as arrow from Tartarian bow.
#Text=When as Aurora ' s infant day new Springs,
#Text=There th '  morning mounting Lark her sweet layes sings.
#Text=The harmonious Thrush, swift Pigeon, Turtle Dove
#Text=Who to her Mate doth ever constant prove.
#Text=The Turkey, Pheasant, Heathcock, Partridge rare,
#Text=The Carrion-tearing Crow, and hurtful Stare;
#Text=The long-liv ' d Raven, th '  ominous Screach-Owl,
#Text=Who tell (as old wives say) disasters foul.
#Text=The drowsie Madge that leaves her day-lov ' d nest
#Text=To fly abroad when day-birds are at rest:
#Text=The Eele murthering Hern, and greedy Cormorant,
#Text=That neer the Creeks in Moorish Marshes haunt.
#Text=The bellowing Bittern, with the long legg ' d Crane.
#Text=Presaging Winters hard, and dearth of Graine.
